[start of motion plan]
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish break the wrist while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: {DESCRIPTION: Think very carefully about the estimated mass, material, stiffness, friction coefficient of the object based off the visual information and semantic knowledge about the object. If object is articulated, do the same reasoning for whatever joint / degree of freedom enables motion. }.
- Environmental Factors: {DESCRIPTION: Think very carefully about the various environmental factors in task like gravity, surface friction, damping, hinge resistance that would interact with the object over the course of the task}.
- The relevant object is {DESCRIPTION: the wrist of the robot, assumed to be aluminum or steel, with some compliance due to joints and potentially plastic components. I will assume the wrist has significant internal resistance and damping} has mass {0.5} kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of {0.5}.
- The surface of interaction is {DESCRIPTION: the robot's own body, which is rigid and will provide significant resistance to the breaking action} has a static friction coefficient of {0.7} with the object.
- Contact Types: {DESCRIPTION: grasping the wrist firmly, applying torque to bend or break it against the robot arm}.
- Motion Type: {DESCRIPTION: applying a rotational force to overcome the wrist's internal resistance to bending}.
- Contact Considerations: {DESCRIPTION: maintaining a firm grasp is crucial. Downward force may also be necessary to hold the wrist in place against the arm during the breaking action}.
- Motion along axes: {DESCRIPTION: the robot exerts motion in a “rotational” fashion along the wrist's [rx, ry] axes}.
- Task duration: {DESCRIPTION: the task will likely take 5 seconds to slowly apply the required force}.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: {DESCRIPTION: wrist mass (m), gravity (g), friction coefficient (mu), approximate yield strength of wrist material, wrist joint internal resistance}.
- Relevant equations: {DESCRIPTION: torque = force * distance, friction force = mu * normal force}.
- Relevant assumptions: {DESCRIPTION: the wrist will bend or break near a joint, not in the middle of a solid component. The resistance is high, but breakable with enough torque}.
- Computations: {DESCRIPTION: estimate torque needed to overcome wrist's bending resistance}.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass {0.5} kg and static friction coefficient of {0.5} along the surface: {DESCRIPTION: Estimate the force required to overcome the wrist's internal resistance and cause a bending motion. Since the wrist is assumed to have significant internal resistance to bending, a torque must be applied to overcome this resistance. This resistance is hard to quantify without knowledge of the material properties, but I will guess that the internal resistance provides 1 Nm of resistance. To overcome this and begin bending, a slightly higher torque must be applied}.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the breaking motion primarily involves rotational torque. No significant linear force along the X-axis is anticipated, but a small force may be needed to keep the wrist against the arm}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: no} force along the X-axis with magnitude {0.0} N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the breaking motion primarily involves rotational torque. No significant linear force along the Y-axis is anticipated}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: no} force along the Y-axis with magnitude {0.0} N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: a negative force along the z-axis might be helpful to hold the wrist against the rest of the arm for leverage while applying the breaking force}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: linear negative} force along the Z-axis with magnitude {2.0} N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the primary breaking motion involves applying a torque around the X-axis to bend/break the wrist. This may require some torque in the clockwise direction in the workspace camera view}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular clockwise} torque about the X-axis with magnitude {3.0} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: a smaller torque around the Y-axis may be required to further bend the wrist during the breaking motion, either clockwise or counterclockwise. I'll guess counterclockwise}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular counterclockwise} torque about the Y-axis with magnitude {1.0} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the breaking motion primarily involves torque around the X and Y-axis. No significant torque around the Z-axis is anticipated}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular no} torque about the Z-axis with magnitude {0.0} N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force:  {DESCRIPTION: the gripper needs to hold the wrist firmly to apply the breaking force. I'll assume 50 N is sufficient to hold it against the reaction forces and internal friction}, thus {50.0} to {60.0} N .

```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The robot wrist, assumed to be metal and somewhat flexible, with a mass of approximately 0.5 kg. It has joints with significant internal resistance."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Grasp the wrist firmly and apply torque around the X-axis and Y-axis to bend or break it, holding it in place by pressing it against the robot arm in the negative Z direction."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [0.0, 0.0, -2.0, -3.0, 1.0, 0.0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 55.0
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 5.0
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
